docs.lead_paragraph: I am plastered against the side of a large rock, 15 feet above a patch of trampled dirt in Central Park. My fingers are wedged inside a fissure. My left toe is balanced on a protrusion about the size of a golf ball and my right toe is balanced on . . . I don't know what it's balanced on. Below me my friend, Ivan Greene, the director of climbing at Chelsea Piers, shouts encouragement. ''Smear your right foot onto the rock,'' he says helpfully, ''Twist your left hip in, stand up, and grab that giant knob just above you.''

headline.main: Getting a Grip on a Clump of Molecules

docs.abstract: Liz Neporent article on learning to 'boulder,' form of rock climging that involves more lateral than vertical movement; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For months, the 72-year-old woman had not been herself. Her mind seemed to have dulled, and her mood had turned flat. Doctors at one hospital diagnosed depression. But when she became feverish and confused, her family took her to another hospital. Doctors there, at the Boston University School of Medicine, discovered that she had meningitis, an infection of the membranes enclosing the brain and spinal cord. She had probably been infected for months.

headline.main: Pet Bird Is Suspect In Death Of Patient

docs.abstract: Doctors at Boston University Medical School link fungus-caused illness in patient to droppings from pet bird; note fungus rarely makes healthy people sick, attacking only those with weakened immune systems; report findings in Annals of Internal Medicine; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There is good news on the nutrition front. Nuts -- yes, fatty nuts -- are back on the menu, even for people on diets to prevent heart disease or cancer or to lose weight. Packed with nutrients needed to start a new generation of plants, nuts are increasingly being recognized as powerhouses of health-promoting substances, especially for people who need to lower their cholesterol, triglycerides or blood pressure.

headline.main: The Fatty Nut Finds Its Place at the Table

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column notes nuts, despite high fat and caloric content, are powerhouses of health-promoting substances, especially for people seeking to lower their cholesterol, triglycerides or blood pressure; notes nuts provide satiety often missing from fat-free carbohydrates and have been shown to help people adhere to weight-loss diets and to maintain losses; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bill Cunerty, a college teacher and coach in Southern California, has always had trouble picking color-coordinated clothes and socks that match. And like many ''colorblind'' people, he tells the color of a traffic light by its position, not its hue. But Mr. Cunerty has been trying out new glasses that, he says, allow him to distinguish colors better. ''For me this has been like watching 'The Wizard of Oz,' '' he said. ''The first half is in black and white, and the second half is in color.''

headline.main: A New Technology That Colors the World (Sort of)

docs.abstract: A New Technology That Colors the World (Sort of)**ColorMax Technologies Inc has developed glasses that let 'colorblind' people distinguish colors better; experts warn lenses do not make people see colors as people with normal vision do and can make it harder to distinguish some colors; diagram (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For women who are facing difficult decisions because they carry a gene that heightens their risk of breast cancer, doctors have developed a bracingly rational, cut-to-the chase method of helping them weigh the pros and cons of various strategies for reducing risk. The new method, based on statistics and mathematical modeling, looks at different options for cancer prevention and gives approximate answers to one crucial question: how much time will each option add to a woman's life?

headline.main: Scientists Do the Math to Fight Breast Cancer

docs.abstract: Doctors have developed new method, based on statistics and methematical modeling, to help women who carry gene that heightens their risk of breast cancer weigh pros and cons of various strategies for reducing risk; technique, described in American Medical Association Journal, was devised specifically for women with gene who have already had breast cancer; table; photo (M)
